instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT is the voltage rail for the backlight of the LCD screen. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: I've done a few no backlights on Airs, but I have never done an older style Pro, so I wanna make sure I get on the right track. I tried a PRAM reset to begin with, but no go. There is no sign of liquid damage anywhere on the board it looks as clean as can be (too clean actually). Took the board out tried a known good 2012 LCD and got nothing, so I started measuring. <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> in diode mode is 0.31 but fluctuates quite a bit. Is it something obvious like a feedback via, or LED driver for sure, or something obvious with that value? I just don't want to remove things like a moron but rather start on the right track and learn something. Any ideas?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: What is the voltage on LCDBKLT? 100% sure image is present?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: 100% sure image is present checked with flashlight on Apple logo. Will measure voltage tomorrow and report back

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Ok so measured voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>: When you first plug in the charger, the voltage starts at 1 volt and drops. Checked the fuse, 12.56 volts on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> side, and zero volts on the other so I would assume it's ok? Checked <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> on pins 3 and 4: Pin 4 was 0 volts, pin 3 was 0 volts. <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> measuring normal same as <CAPACITOR>C9782</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> measuring normal.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: So voltage actually starts at about 1.2 volts then drops to 0.05 volts before recycling back to 1.2 volts then back down in a loop. I let it drop for 30 seconds before it went back up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Uhh one side of the fuse has 12V and the other side has nothing, tell me what is wrong there.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Damn I feel really stupid Duke lol I just read back at what I said my mind was in like a million places. Ok so my question then I guess for an electrical understanding kind of thing would be what could cause the fuse to blow if there is no sign of liquid damage?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Something shorted the backlight output. Measure resistance to GND with the LCD plugged in and all power removed. Could be a short in the cable/LCD or that a shorted LCD assembly was plugged in at some point.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Ok will do. Definitely want to avoid a return if that's the case.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Checked resistance with LCD plugged in and all power removed and compared it to a working <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> we have in the store for sale, and all of the values came back nearly identical. I'm pretty sure it's good but did warn customer of the screen. I think we can consider this case closed thank you for all the help Duke I'm very grateful for it.
